snippet: LEAD: When it opened in 1957, the Nimitz Freeway in Oakland was an engineering marvel. The story of how it became a concrete graveyard is the story of California's century of attempts to define what makes a structure withstand an earthquake....
lead_paragraph: LEAD: When it opened in 1957, the Nimitz Freeway in Oakland was an engineering marvel. The story of how it became a concrete graveyard is the story of California's century of attempts to define what makes a structure withstand an earthquake.

headline.main: Building Codes: Designs for Last Quake, Not Next

byline.original: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times
